BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY

18, 1915.

MR. KISTLER : VERNON CASTLE

MR. KEYSER ON HOMEWOOD SITE
President of Trustees Says While It Is Not
Impossible, It Is Improbable That
We Shall Move Next Year.

"While it is not absolutely impossible, it is highly improbable that
we shall be able to move the University to Homewood during the next
year." This is the statement made
by Mr. R. Brent Keyser, president
of the Board of Trustees, to a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER
last week,
"Work on the new buildings is
progressing very slowly; in fact, no
development worthy of special attention has taken place in the situation for quite a long time. The
work that we have been able to do
has been done. The work that we
want to do—and that is the work
that will have to be done before we
can get to Homewood—cannot be
done until we have the means."
Mr. Keyser fears that the University is fated to remain on Monument street for some time. He admitted that it will stay there longer
than was originally thought, but he
finds some consolation in the delay.
"We do not want to get into the
new home too speedily. That would
make it very pleasant for the present students, and would make the
trustees and faculty very happy, but
if we rushed the situation we might
do something for which we should
be sorry later.
"It is wisest to study the situation slowly and with a great deal
of thought. We are not building
the new site with a view to the
advantage of the present members
of the University. We must consider and plan for future years, and
this is not the wtirk of an hour.
"We are going to work slowly
and surely, and when the University
is moved it will rest upon such a
firm foundation as will justify the
present policy of the trustees—the
policy of 'watchful waiting.'"
The work that has been done on
the Homewood estate has been
purely preliminary. Grading of the
grounds has been completed and
stakes have been driven to mark
off the boundaries of the buildings
that are to be. Gilman Hall, the
center of the group, is completed;
the Mechanical and Electrical Engineering Building is in use by the
technical students, and the power
plant is about to be put in operation.
This plant will supply heat, light
and power for the Engineering
Building and it is probable that
wires may be strung to Homewood
Field for powerful arc lights to be
used during the football practices.

SWIMMERS HAVE FOUR

DATES PLANS FOR SOPH-FRESHIE MEET

Meets With Navy, Swarthmore, City
College and Marston's Have Been
Scheduled by the Manager.

List of Events and Names of Candidates
Announced Wright and Rosen Are
Two New Varsity Track Men.

The schedule of the recently
organized independent swimming
team is rounding into shape. Four
meets have been arranged, two in
Baltimore ad two away from
home.
On January 30, City College will
be met in a practice contest in the
Central Young Men's Christian Association pool. The following Friday night, February 5, Manager
Richardson has booked another
school team (Marston's) for a meet
at the Baltimore Athletic Club.
It is hoped that the swimming
squad will get a great deal of valuable practice from these encounters with the school teams, and that
it will be in good form to meet
Swarthmore College. on Saturday,
February 13, at Swarthmore. This
trip promises to be a pleasant one,
and the meet to be close, as the
Swarthmore swimmers are in the
same position as those at Hopkins,
not being recognized by the Athletic Association officially.
The Navy will be met on February 20 at Annapolis, and, as this
is about the hardest meet on the
schedule so far, the team is training in such a way as to be in the
pink of condition for the affair.
There is a possibility of a meet
with Princeton, to take place late
in February in Baltimore. Negotiations have been started for this,
and the results will be known soon.
Mercersburg Academy is another
possible opponent.
Five practices have been held in
the Young Men's Christian Association pool, and the showing of
the candidates has been most encouraging to the followers of the
team. Fulton, Pepper, Captain
Rowland, Dick Woodward, NicholSon and Eiseman have all shown
excellent form in the fifty and
hundred yard dashes, and Bartlett, Strobel and several others are
about ready to give good accounts
of themselves in the 220. Brinton, Fricke, - Nicholson and Eiseman are all plunging over fifty feet,
and should improve greatly before
the first meet comes off.

The track squad has been divided
into two parts, one for the relay
men and the other for those who
are going to take part in other
events. There are only fifteen men
out for the relay team and most
of these are green material, so the
prospects of the team are not As
bright as they might be, but even
though there is no old material except the members of last year's
freshman relay it is hoped that the
team may make a good showing in
the events of the coming season.
Of the brightest prospects among
the new men are Wright and Rosen. The former, a first-year Medical School student, came from the
University of Washington State,
and is a dash man. The general
opinion, however, is that he will
show up better out of doors in the
spring events than in those to come
in the next few months. Rosen is
from the University of Michigan
and has had considerable experience in cross-country running.
He is especially good at the mile.
The most important indoor meets
of the season take place next month
and are'as follows:
George Washington games, February 13, at Washington.
Fifth Regiment games, February
20, at the Armory.
Georgetown games, February 27,
at Washington.
An event of much interest and
discussion at the present time is the
sophomore-freshman track meet,
which is to be held in the cage on
Saturday, January 23. There has
been some discussion at to whether
there would be a 220-yard dash,
but it has been finally decided to
have this event and also to have a
shot-putting contest. The list of
events are:
Thirty-yard' dash.
Thirty-yard hurdles.
Two hundred and twenty yard
dash.
Four hundred and forty yard
dash.
Eight hundred and eighty yard
run.

Little ,Gym Instructor Teaches Class of
Twenty Freshmen How to Dance.
There is Much Enthusiasm.

The innovation of innovations has
been introduced into the life of the
Class of 1918. From it will come
grace, savoir faire, perfect assurance and nonchalance for the freshman; it will fashion him into a wellpoised, polished person of superior
knowledge; it will bring him fully
within the genus honzo.
In short, Mr. Kistler, erstwhile
instructor of the gymnasium class,
maker of stalwart bodies out of
studious freshmen, has organized
twenty of his charges into a dancing class.
In the words of this diminutive
Mordkin, the new Hopkins activity
should accomplish four objects,
viz.: "It should help the men physically in becoming graceful and in
learning how to handle themselves;
it should help them in becoming
more intimately acquainted with
their classmates; it should help the
cotillons by causing more men to
be interested in dancing; and it
should help me in getting in closer
touch with the men whom I am
teaching."
The details of this altruistic plan
have been completed and the class,
eager for personal intimacy with
the elusive fox trot and Kistlerian
one-step, has twice crowded into
the gymnasium and received the
rudiments of its ballroom training.
Wednesday night has been set apart
for the instruction.
The course includes ten lessons,
and Mr. Kistler has set only a
nominal fee for the entire series.
He has not organized the delightful
meetings for his own benefit, but
for the advantage of the freshmen
who lack a certain grace and lissomeness of movement.
So far everything has gone along
in a manner highly pleasing both
to instructor and pupils. The only
jarring element which has cropped
up has been the obvious fact, that
the gymnasium was never built for
a ballroom, and thus does not offer
many conveniences for the young
ladies who serve as partners. This
is the only speck on the horizon.
Mr. Kistler has arranged to give
two informal dances to his class
later in the year, probably at the
Garrison Country Club. Thus it
appears that the twenty fortunate
freshmen have not only contracted
to learn how to dance, but also to
have a thoroughly good time.
The class is thoroughly and unreservedly delighted with Mr. Kistler, Mr. Kistler is enthusiastic about
his proteges and everything seems
to be going in a way that may soon
rival the festivities of Castle House.

Architecture" was delivered in McCoy Hall last Friday by Dr. Luther

The Professor and the Pedant.

Prof. Thomas R. Lounsbury, of
Yale, is a foe to the purist and
the pedant, as his brilliant essays
show. He who insists on saying
"tomorrow will be Thursday" will
find no champion in Professor
Lounsbury.
On a New England vacation the
Professor, gazing out across the
lake one gray and sultry afternoon,
remarked:
"It looks like rain."
A pedant was rocking in a rocking chair near by.
"What looks like rain, Professor?" he chuckled. "Ha, ha! I've
got you there! What looks like
rain?'
"Water," Professor Lounsbury
answered -coldly.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 18, 1915.

JUNIORS DISCUSS WEIGHTY
MATTERS AT CLASS MEETING

THREE HOPKINS MEN TO HELP
JUDGE CONTEST AT GOUCHER

At a meeting of the Junior Class,
held last Tuesday at one o'clock,
several matters of importance were
considered and acted upon.
A motion to appropriate five dollars for the use of the Student
Council was passed. After this the
possibility of haying a relay team to
represent the juniors against the
seniors in the freshman-sophomore
meet was discussed, but while the
majority of the class seemed to
favor the plan of perpetuating this
traditional form of inter-class rivalry, the election of a captain to take
charge of the organization of a
team was deferred.
• Tom Troxell, of the 1915 Hullabaloo Board, next addressed the
juniors; and acquainted them with
the plan of the Board to assign to
each class at the University a definite number of pages in the yearbook, to be filled in any manner
that they might desire. Mr. Coffin
was unanimously chosen •by the
third-year men to write the class
history, and take general charge of
filling the space allotted by the Hullabaloo Board.
A report was made by the editor
of the 1916 Hullabaloo, who discussed the work that the junior editors hope to accomplish during the
present year. The names of the
members of the Banquet Committee were then read by the president,
and a report by the committee was
promised for the next class meeting.
The juniors hope to give an even
more interesting, novel and entertaining feast than those arranged
in the two earlier years of their
Hopkins career.
The inevitable plea for dues was
next made by the eloquent treasurer
of the class, Mr. Leitheiser, in
whom frequent practice at this particular type of harangue has developed a kind of professional fluency.
The scanty attendance and general
lack of enthusiasm manifested in
class affairs by the juniors in general next received the scorn of the
presiding officer, and the meeting
was adjpurned.

Another indication that no prophet is without honor save in his own
country was recently afforded when
three Hopkins undergraduates, a
senior and two juniors, were chosen
to be among the judges in the
"Kalends Contest," an inter-class
activity held annually at Goucher
College.
The "Kalends" is the monthly
magazine published at Goucher, and
is a periodical remarkable both for
the merit of its literary contributions and the thoroughly businesslike manner in which it is managed
and edited. Every year a contest
is held among the four classes at
Goucher, each striving to produce
the best issue of the magazine. The
book which, in the opinion of the
majority of the judges of the contest, is possessed of the highest degree of merit and literary distinction, is finally issued as a regular
number of the "Kalends," with the
numerals of the victorious class
proudly emblazoned on its covers.
The action of the Goucher classes
in choosing three Hopkins men as
arbiters in the contest is indeed an
unprecedented one, and one deeply
to be appreciated by those whom
their selection honored. It is impossible, of course, to divulge the
names of any of the judges before
their decisions have beeen duly
made and submitted.

DR.KUNO MEYER TELLS OF IRISH
POETRY AND ANCIENT RACES

DR. DARGAN TO GIVE TWO
MONTHS' GRADUATE WORK

Dr. E. P. Dargan, of the Romance Department of the University
of Chicago, will arrive at the University this week to give graduate
instruction in French literature for
the months of February and March.
This work was seriously interrupted
by the fact that Prof. Andre Morize
remained in France to fight for his
country when the war broke out in
August.
Dr. Dargan is one of the most
distinguished Romance scholars in
the country. He comes to Hopkins
on a two months' vacation from
Chicago, and will take up the work
of Prof. Morize, conducting two
lecture courses and a closed seminary during the time that he is
here.
The new professor is a doctor of
philosophy from Johns Hopkins,
having received his degree in 1906.
He has been instructor at the University of Virginia, and has done
important editing work in Romance.

Alex. Wolfe Elected Captain.
The freshman-track squad elected
Alexander M. Wolfe as their captam at its organization meeting on
Monday. Although three other
candidates were nominated, Alec
was elected unanimously on the first
ballot.

from City College, where he played
football and lacrosse. He has not
had any experience in track work,
but he is a good organizer and has
speed that may make him a good
man on the track.
The candidates for the team
signed up for the events which they
would like to enter. Captain Wolfe
will hold try-outs for these men as
.spon as possible.

will be run by each man. Merrick,
Spencer, Prince, Tarr and Baker
are the senior team. Penniman,
Hayes, Niles, Hutton, Beck and
Knipp will try to land places on the

MR. KISTLER : VERNON CASTLE

MR. KEYSER ON HOMEWOOD SITE
President of Trustees Says While It Is Not
Impossible, It Is Improbable That
We Shall Move Next Year.

"While it is not absolutely impossible, it is highly improbable that
we shall be able to move the University to Homewood during the next
year." This is the statement made
by Mr. R. Brent Keyser, president
of the Board of Trustees, to a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER
last week,
"Work on the new buildings is
progressing very slowly; in fact, no
development worthy of special attention has taken place in the situation for quite a long time. The
work that we have been able to do
has been done. The work that we
want to do—and that is the work
that will have to be done before we
can get to Homewood—cannot be
done until we have the means."
Mr. Keyser fears that the University is fated to remain on Monument street for some time. He admitted that it will stay there longer
than was originally thought, but he
finds some consolation in the delay.
"We do not want to get into the
new home too speedily. That would
make it very pleasant for the present students, and would make the
trustees and faculty very happy, but
if we rushed the situation we might
do something for which we should
be sorry later.
"It is wisest to study the situation slowly and with a great deal
of thought. We are not building
the new site with a view to the
advantage of the present members
of the University. We must consider and plan for future years, and
this is not the wtirk of an hour.
"We are going to work slowly
and surely, and when the University
is moved it will rest upon such a
firm foundation as will justify the
present policy of the trustees—the
policy of 'watchful waiting.'"
The work that has been done on
the Homewood estate has been
purely preliminary. Grading of the
grounds has been completed and
stakes have been driven to mark
off the boundaries of the buildings
that are to be. Gilman Hall, the
center of the group, is completed;
the Mechanical and Electrical Engineering Building is in use by the
technical students, and the power
plant is about to be put in operation.
This plant will supply heat, light
and power for the Engineering
Building and it is probable that
wires may be strung to Homewood
Field for powerful arc lights to be
used during the football practices.

SWIMMERS HAVE FOUR

DATES PLANS FOR SOPH-FRESHIE MEET

Meets With Navy, Swarthmore, City
College and Marston's Have Been
Scheduled by the Manager.

List of Events and Names of Candidates
Announced Wright and Rosen Are
Two New Varsity Track Men.

The schedule of the recently
organized independent swimming
team is rounding into shape. Four
meets have been arranged, two in
Baltimore ad two away from
home.
On January 30, City College will
be met in a practice contest in the
Central Young Men's Christian Association pool. The following Friday night, February 5, Manager
Richardson has booked another
school team (Marston's) for a meet
at the Baltimore Athletic Club.
It is hoped that the swimming
squad will get a great deal of valuable practice from these encounters with the school teams, and that
it will be in good form to meet
Swarthmore College. on Saturday,
February 13, at Swarthmore. This
trip promises to be a pleasant one,
and the meet to be close, as the
Swarthmore swimmers are in the
same position as those at Hopkins,
not being recognized by the Athletic Association officially.
The Navy will be met on February 20 at Annapolis, and, as this
is about the hardest meet on the
schedule so far, the team is training in such a way as to be in the
pink of condition for the affair.
There is a possibility of a meet
with Princeton, to take place late
in February in Baltimore. Negotiations have been started for this,
and the results will be known soon.
Mercersburg Academy is another
possible opponent.
Five practices have been held in
the Young Men's Christian Association pool, and the showing of
the candidates has been most encouraging to the followers of the
team. Fulton, Pepper, Captain
Rowland, Dick Woodward, NicholSon and Eiseman have all shown
excellent form in the fifty and
hundred yard dashes, and Bartlett, Strobel and several others are
about ready to give good accounts
of themselves in the 220. Brinton, Fricke, - Nicholson and Eiseman are all plunging over fifty feet,
and should improve greatly before
the first meet comes off.

The track squad has been divided
into two parts, one for the relay
men and the other for those who
are going to take part in other
events. There are only fifteen men
out for the relay team and most
of these are green material, so the
prospects of the team are not As
bright as they might be, but even
though there is no old material except the members of last year's
freshman relay it is hoped that the
team may make a good showing in
the events of the coming season.
Of the brightest prospects among
the new men are Wright and Rosen. The former, a first-year Medical School student, came from the
University of Washington State,
and is a dash man. The general
opinion, however, is that he will
show up better out of doors in the
spring events than in those to come
in the next few months. Rosen is
from the University of Michigan
and has had considerable experience in cross-country running.
He is especially good at the mile.
The most important indoor meets
of the season take place next month
and are'as follows:
George Washington games, February 13, at Washington.
Fifth Regiment games, February
20, at the Armory.
Georgetown games, February 27,
at Washington.
An event of much interest and
discussion at the present time is the
sophomore-freshman track meet,
which is to be held in the cage on
Saturday, January 23. There has
been some discussion at to whether
there would be a 220-yard dash,
but it has been finally decided to
have this event and also to have a
shot-putting contest. The list of
events are:
Thirty-yard' dash.
Thirty-yard hurdles.
Two hundred and twenty yard
dash.
Four hundred and forty yard
dash.
Eight hundred and eighty yard
run.

Little ,Gym Instructor Teaches Class of
Twenty Freshmen How to Dance.
There is Much Enthusiasm.

The innovation of innovations has
been introduced into the life of the
Class of 1918. From it will come
grace, savoir faire, perfect assurance and nonchalance for the freshman; it will fashion him into a wellpoised, polished person of superior
knowledge; it will bring him fully
within the genus honzo.
In short, Mr. Kistler, erstwhile
instructor of the gymnasium class,
maker of stalwart bodies out of
studious freshmen, has organized
twenty of his charges into a dancing class.
In the words of this diminutive
Mordkin, the new Hopkins activity
should accomplish four objects,
viz.: "It should help the men physically in becoming graceful and in
learning how to handle themselves;
it should help them in becoming
more intimately acquainted with
their classmates; it should help the
cotillons by causing more men to
be interested in dancing; and it
should help me in getting in closer
touch with the men whom I am
teaching."
The details of this altruistic plan
have been completed and the class,
eager for personal intimacy with
the elusive fox trot and Kistlerian
one-step, has twice crowded into
the gymnasium and received the
rudiments of its ballroom training.
Wednesday night has been set apart
for the instruction.
The course includes ten lessons,
and Mr. Kistler has set only a
nominal fee for the entire series.
He has not organized the delightful
meetings for his own benefit, but
for the advantage of the freshmen
who lack a certain grace and lissomeness of movement.
So far everything has gone along
in a manner highly pleasing both
to instructor and pupils. The only
jarring element which has cropped
up has been the obvious fact, that
the gymnasium was never built for
a ballroom, and thus does not offer
many conveniences for the young
ladies who serve as partners. This
is the only speck on the horizon.
Mr. Kistler has arranged to give
two informal dances to his class
later in the year, probably at the
Garrison Country Club. Thus it
appears that the twenty fortunate
freshmen have not only contracted
to learn how to dance, but also to
have a thoroughly good time.
The class is thoroughly and unreservedly delighted with Mr. Kistler, Mr. Kistler is enthusiastic about
his proteges and everything seems
to be going in a way that may soon
rival the festivities of Castle House.

The Professor and the Pedant.

Prof. Thomas R. Lounsbury, of
Yale, is a foe to the purist and
the pedant, as his brilliant essays
show. He who insists on saying
"tomorrow will be Thursday" will
find no champion in Professor
Lounsbury.
On a New England vacation the
Professor, gazing out across the
lake one gray and sultry afternoon,
remarked:
"It looks like rain."
A pedant was rocking in a rocking chair near by.
"What looks like rain, Professor?" he chuckled. "Ha, ha! I've
got you there! What looks like
rain?'
"Water," Professor Lounsbury
answered -coldly.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 18, 1915.

JUNIORS DISCUSS WEIGHTY
MATTERS AT CLASS MEETING

THREE HOPKINS MEN TO HELP
JUDGE CONTEST AT GOUCHER

At a meeting of the Junior Class,
held last Tuesday at one o'clock,
several matters of importance were
considered and acted upon.
A motion to appropriate five dollars for the use of the Student
Council was passed. After this the
possibility of haying a relay team to
represent the juniors against the
seniors in the freshman-sophomore
meet was discussed, but while the
majority of the class seemed to
favor the plan of perpetuating this
traditional form of inter-class rivalry, the election of a captain to take
charge of the organization of a
team was deferred.
• Tom Troxell, of the 1915 Hullabaloo Board, next addressed the
juniors; and acquainted them with
the plan of the Board to assign to
each class at the University a definite number of pages in the yearbook, to be filled in any manner
that they might desire. Mr. Coffin
was unanimously chosen •by the
third-year men to write the class
history, and take general charge of
filling the space allotted by the Hullabaloo Board.
A report was made by the editor
of the 1916 Hullabaloo, who discussed the work that the junior editors hope to accomplish during the
present year. The names of the
members of the Banquet Committee were then read by the president,
and a report by the committee was
promised for the next class meeting.
The juniors hope to give an even
more interesting, novel and entertaining feast than those arranged
in the two earlier years of their
Hopkins career.
The inevitable plea for dues was
next made by the eloquent treasurer
of the class, Mr. Leitheiser, in
whom frequent practice at this particular type of harangue has developed a kind of professional fluency.
The scanty attendance and general
lack of enthusiasm manifested in
class affairs by the juniors in general next received the scorn of the
presiding officer, and the meeting
was adjpurned.

Another indication that no prophet is without honor save in his own
country was recently afforded when
three Hopkins undergraduates, a
senior and two juniors, were chosen
to be among the judges in the
"Kalends Contest," an inter-class
activity held annually at Goucher
College.
The "Kalends" is the monthly
magazine published at Goucher, and
is a periodical remarkable both for
the merit of its literary contributions and the thoroughly businesslike manner in which it is managed
and edited. Every year a contest
is held among the four classes at
Goucher, each striving to produce
the best issue of the magazine. The
book which, in the opinion of the
majority of the judges of the contest, is possessed of the highest degree of merit and literary distinction, is finally issued as a regular
number of the "Kalends," with the
numerals of the victorious class
proudly emblazoned on its covers.
The action of the Goucher classes
in choosing three Hopkins men as
arbiters in the contest is indeed an
unprecedented one, and one deeply
to be appreciated by those whom
their selection honored. It is impossible, of course, to divulge the
names of any of the judges before
their decisions have beeen duly
made and submitted.

DR.KUNO MEYER TELLS OF IRISH
POETRY AND ANCIENT RACES

DR. DARGAN TO GIVE TWO
MONTHS' GRADUATE WORK

Dr. E. P. Dargan, of the Romance Department of the University
of Chicago, will arrive at the University this week to give graduate
instruction in French literature for
the months of February and March.
This work was seriously interrupted
by the fact that Prof. Andre Morize
remained in France to fight for his
country when the war broke out in
August.
Dr. Dargan is one of the most
distinguished Romance scholars in
the country. He comes to Hopkins
on a two months' vacation from
Chicago, and will take up the work
of Prof. Morize, conducting two
lecture courses and a closed seminary during the time that he is
here.
The new professor is a doctor of
philosophy from Johns Hopkins,
having received his degree in 1906.
He has been instructor at the University of Virginia, and has done
important editing work in Romance.

Alex. Wolfe Elected Captain.
The freshman-track squad elected
Alexander M. Wolfe as their captam at its organization meeting on
Monday. Although three other
candidates were nominated, Alec
was elected unanimously on the first
ballot.
Captain Wolfe came to Hopkins
from City College, where he played
football and lacrosse. He has not
had any experience in track work,
but he is a good organizer and has
speed that may make him a good
man on the track.
The candidates for the team
signed up for the events which they
would like to enter. Captain Wolfe
will hold try-outs for these men as
.spon as possible.
The juniors and seniors will compete in a relay race. Four men will
represent each side and three laps
will be run by each man. Merrick,
Spencer, Prince, Tarr and Baker
are the senior team. Penniman,
Hayes, Niles, Hutton, Beck and
Knipp will try to land places on the
th rd -year team.
